title: Private traits and attributes are predictable from digital records of human behavior

author: Thore Graepel, Microsoft Research, Cambridge, Microsoft Research

segmentation: Alright, thank you very much.
I'll try and entertain you.

I perceive that as part of the role here in particular as the day progresses, I'm going to talk about quite a fun project that we have under the title of the human manifold and it's about the predictability of human online behavior and peoples, private traits and attributes and so on.
It's joint work with folks at Cambridge and also with people at Cambridge University in particular.
Christian Ski and David Stillwell so.
We all leave a lot of traces in the online world, and there's for example various social media sites where we leave traces, but also there's the music we listen to.
The books we read, the stuff we buy, the movies we watch, whatever we pay for, what we search for, and so on.
So about any single individual.
There's this enormous amount of debt.
ETA and I'll take the very simple view here that each one of these bits of data are a dimension in a given space.

You can think of a person being part of this huge network related to being related to other people, but also being related to various bits of content to their likes on Facebook to the movies they watched on Netflix.
Anne.

And all of these things, and the key thing that we'll be looking at here in this work is that while this is a very high dimensional space, there's really a low dimensional manifold that allows us to make predictions.
Here's there's an awful lot of correlations here, and the task in this talk will be to look at these correlations.
See how we can use them for prediction, and also try to find some interpretable explanations for the kinds of correlations that we see.
Anne.
So why would it make sense to map this human manifold?
Think of this manifold as like 7 billion points in this very high dimensional space.
Well, scientifically, we think it might help us better understand human behavior.
Can better understand the commonality and individual differences among people if we understand what this manifold is and also if we just look at the field of psychometric's.
You know people are measuring personality and IQ and so on.

And I'll show some results pertaining to that particular thing.

It's not a trivial one.

If we knew all that, we could really improve user experience.
So the idea will be to find interpretable dimensions such as personality, intelligence, happiness and so on, and map the manifold in those terms.

Yeah, I mean a lot of actually factor analysis was developed in the context of developing these, so they're not necessarily orthogonal.

I mean they wouldn't want the same thing to be measured by by two different dimensions.
So why would we be able to do this explicit analysis of the human manifold?
It's mainly due to a particular data source that my two collaborators created.
It's called my personality and so this is really the result of a Facebook app that was launched in 2008 where people can go to that Facebook app and do all kinds of personality tests.
